page.title: 04"TATTIE PICKING" BY BRECHIN
page.content: Unlike most crops{potatoes}are not all harvested by machines but many acres are still picked by hand by casual labour-mainly schoolchildren and mothers.Farmers supply transport to the fields in time for an 8a.m. start. The day lasts 8 hours with several breaks to eat.It is hectic first thing in the morning as the farmer divides the field into{"bits"}to be picked. Younger children can get part bits. The tractor, pulling a digger, turns over the earth revealing the potatoes and the picker puts them into a large plastic basket. Another tractor pulling a{"bogey"(trailer)}collects the potatoes and takes them to the storing shed in wooden boxes.A picker earns a set wage of about{Â£10}a day.The season lasts for three weeks and local schools get an extended autumn holiday.
